paragraphs.name: bd3d
paragraphs.text: Gratitude is a key contributor for team performance. It’s also something that improves your own happiness the more you use it.

paragraphs.name: 774a
paragraphs.text: One way to do that is to avoid the old adage about packing bad feedback into a sandwich of good feedback. How you present information matters, but the ‘sh*t sandwich’ technique tends to seem inauthentic, and worse, it often fails to successfully deliver your key critique.
Feedback

paragraphs.name: f1c7
paragraphs.text: So, be bold, move fast, but always remember that you can’t do it alone. Ultimately, you can only lead people who choose to work for you, and those people want to know that you’ll care enough about them to invest in their success.

paragraphs.name: ee9e
paragraphs.text: really great take on leadership…
Matt Trainer, you might really enjoy Tom Döhler’s post, The in’s and out’s of feedback. He makes some very good points regarding the fragile nature of feedback.

b5ec24377917.title: Matt Trainer, you might really enjoy Tom Döhler’s post, The in’s and out’s of feedback.

paragraphs.name: 163f
paragraphs.text: Wise advice! Many people don’t know how to lead (including many leaders; just look at our US government).

paragraphs.name: 1b88
paragraphs.text: Very good.

paragraphs.name: 93c5
paragraphs.text: I agree, great post! These are the types of leaders we need in our society today. The time of spouting brainless orders to those “lower” than you are coming to an end.

paragraphs.name: 27b9
paragraphs.text: I’ve seen this first hand. Positive leaders that know how to correctly ‘frame’ feedback always end up being behind a hardworking and efficient team.

paragraphs.name: 7c45
paragraphs.text: Yes! This is a very good point! Feedbacks that go “it’s not that you are not ______ , but…” have a high probabilty of coming off as dismissive and inauthentic because instead of focusing on the issue at hand (what we really want to resolve), we dilute the focus of the conversation with mixed signals.

2b34522cd556.title: Yes! This is a very good point!

paragraphs.text: Too bad the overwhelming majority of management is so clueless on these issues, especially those who are in government. Most management these days has resorted to the control freak or power accumulation mentality, that they forget the people actually get the work done, no matter how much automation and AI exists in their environment.

paragraphs.name: 4a2b
paragraphs.text: Matt, thank you for posting your thoughts around management and leadership. I agree with your points and, as someone in senior leadership, I try to practice these and improve upon them every day. Often, I fail, but I get back up and keep trying. As with other ideas in your piece, that failure and then trying again also sets an example for the people…

paragraphs.text: Matt, you may not know it, but you’re arguing in support of transformative leadership. Transformative leadership emphasize people and relationships rather than the bottom line and profits. You can check out a quick overview of this leadership style, and others, in my post, here.
